facts.text: By the Andhra State Act 1953 (Central Act 30 of 1953), a part of Bellary district (other than Alur, Adoni and Rayadrug taluks) ceased to form part of the State of Madras and was added to the State of Mysore.

By virtue of s. 53 of Central Act 30 of 1953, all laws in force in the territories added to Mysore continued until otherwise provided, making Madras Commercial Crops Market Act 1933 applicable to Bellary district as originally stood.
Section 11(1) of the Act originally empowered Market Committee to levy fees on notified commercial crops bought and sold in notified area.
Madras High Court decisions held the fee under original s.11(1) was really a tax for constructing market, not for services.
Madras legislature amended s.11(1) by Madras Act 33 of 1955, clarifying it as cess by way of sales tax, additional to Madras General Sales Tax Act 1939, subject to Art. 286.
Amendment of 1955 did not apply to Bellary district as it was no longer part of Madras.
By States Reorganisation Act 1956, South Kanara district (except Kollegal taluk etc.) became part of Mysore; s.7(a) continued Madras laws there, including amended s.11.

In 1958, Mysore legislature passed Mysore Amendment and Validation of Levy of Cess Act 1958 (assent Nov 30, 1958), amending s.11(1) for 'Madras area' (deemed from Nov 23, 1955), specifying rates for Arecanut and Coconut.
Mysore Adaptation of Laws Order 1956 and Mysore General Clauses Act 1899 defined 'Madras area' as territories from South Kanara per States Reorganisation Act 1956, excluding Bellary district.
Statement of objects and reasons of 1958 Mysore Act referred only to South Kanara Market Committee and levy there.
Bye-laws of Bellary Market Committee (approved May 1960) under bye-law 19 levied fees on groundnut seeds etc. at 9 paise per kg; schedule included cotton, groundnut, not Arecanut/Coconut.
South Kanara Market Committee bye-laws focused on Arecanut and Coconut.

Mysore Agricultural Produce Marketing Regulation Act, 1966 (Mysore Act 27 of 1966) published Sep 15, 1966; s.154 repealed the Act as in force in Bellary District and separately as in force in Madras Area.
Respondents served notice by Secretary, Bellary Market Committee to pay cess on groundnut seeds bought/sold in notified area.
Respondents failed to comply; complaints filed against them for contravention of s.11(1) and rules/bye-laws.
Respondents filed writ petitions under Art. 226 in Mysore High Court (Nos. 1967, 1968, 1969, 2388 of 1966) challenging validity of cess levy.

High Court judgments dated Aug 22, 23, 1967 quashed demand, holding it was sales tax exceeding max rate under Central Sales Tax Act s.15 and Mysore Sales Tax Act s.54; directed refund of cess collected for 3 years prior.
High Court held 1958 Mysore amendment applied to Bellary district, treating cess as sales tax.

legal_issues.text: Whether the amendment to s.11(1) by Mysore Amendment and Validation of Levy of Cess Act 1958 applied to Bellary district or was confined to Madras Area (South Kanara).
Whether the levy was a sales tax (under amended s.11(1)) or a fee (under original s.11(1)), and if fee, whether related to services.

petitioner_arguments.text: 1958 Mysore amendment did not apply to Bellary district; it was confined to Madras Area (South Kanara); Bellary governed by original s.11(1) allowing only fee.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Andhra State Act 1953 s.53; States Reorganisation Act 1956; Mysore General Clauses Act s.3 cl.47; Mysore Act 27 of 1966 s.154

respondent_arguments.text: Levy was sales tax under amended s.11(1) applicable to Bellary; exceeded max sales tax rates.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Central Sales Tax Act 1956 s.15; Mysore Sales Tax Act 1957 s.54

court_reasoning.text: Bellary district (added to Mysore in 1953) governed by original s.11(1); 1958 amendment confined to Madras Area (South Kanara added in 1956) per statement of objects, definitions, s.154 of 1966 Act, bye-laws.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in disregarding definition of Madras Area; amendment did not apply to Bellary.

court_reasoning.text: Demand was for fee under original s.11(1) at 9 paise/kg on groundnut; validity as fee (not tax) to be determined by High Court re services rendered.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between fee and tax per precedents; remit for evidence on quid pro quo.

holdings.text: 1958 Mysore amendment to s.11(1) did not apply to Bellary district; levy only fee under original s.11(1).
Whether fee levy valid (related to services) to be decided by High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; High Court judgment set aside; cases remitted to Mysore High Court to determine if levy under original s.11(1) is valid fee related to services, with opportunity for affidavits/documents.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand for fresh disposal in accordance with law

key_quotes.text: We have no manner of doubt that the Bellary district which became a part of the State of Mysore as a result of the Central Act 30 of 1953 was governed by s.11(1) of the Act as it stood at the time it had become applicable to that area.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on applicability of original section to Bellary.

key_quotes.text: The distinction between what may be called the Bellary Area and the Madras Area which came to be incorporated in the State of Mysore in 1953 and 1956 respectively is fully substantiated by s.154 of the Mysore Act 27 of 1966.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The distinction between a fee and a tax is well known and there are a series of decisions of this Court on what is a fee and what are the tests which distinguish it from a tax.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directs remand for fee vs tax analysis.
